title: What does the United Nations actually do?

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary purpose of establishing the United Nations in 1945?

options.label: A
options.text: To promote economic growth among its member countries.

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent the outbreak of war and avert a world war.

options.label: C
options.text: To promote cultural exchange among its member countries.

options.label: D
options.text: To address human rights issues globally.

multiple-choice.question: Which two bodies are responsible for passing resolutions to make policy for the world in the United Nations?

options.label: A
options.text: The Security Council and the General Assembly.

options.label: B
options.text: The Economic Council and the Social Council.

options.label: C
options.text: The Human Rights Council and the Culture Council.

options.label: D
options.text: The Peace Council and the Security Council.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the famous document that has been ratified and kept by many countries, outlining human rights?

options.label: A
options.text: The United Nations Declaration of Human Rights.

options.label: B
options.text: The United Nations Charter.

options.label: C
options.text: The United Nations Convention on Human Rights.

options.label: D
options.text: The United Nations Treaty on Human Rights.

multiple-choice.question: Which five countries have permanent membership in the Security Council?

options.label: A
options.text: France, Britain, the United States, China, and Japan.

options.label: B
options.text: France, Britain, the United States, China, and Russia.

options.label: C
options.text: France, Britain, the United States, China, and India.

options.label: D
options.text: France, Britain, the United States, China, and Brazil.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of the United Nations, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To promote economic growth among its member countries.

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent the outbreak of war and avert a world war.

options.label: C
options.text: To promote cultural exchange among its member countries.

options.label: D
options.text: To attain a better future for humanity.

title: I Forgot My Phone

multiple-choice.question: What is self-talk, according to psychologists?

options.label: A
options.text: Verbalized thoughts directed toward others.

options.label: B
options.text: Verbalized thoughts directed toward oneself or some facet of one's life.

options.label: C
options.text: Silent thoughts directed toward oneself or some facet of one's life.

options.label: D
options.text: Non-verbalized thoughts directed toward oneself or some facet of one's life.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of self-talk in children's development, according to Lev Vygotsky?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a sign of mental instability.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a key to development, as it helps children practice managing their behaviors and emotions.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a sign of emotional maturity.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a sign of cognitive decline.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of engaging in self-talk that is instructional or motivational on one's attitude and performance?

options.label: A
options.text: It decreases focus and boosts self-doubt.

options.label: B
options.text: It increases focus, boosts self-esteem, and helps tackle everyday tasks.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on attitude and performance.

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases self-esteem and boosts anxiety.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential negative effect of high levels of negative self-talk on mental health?

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to increased creativity and problem-solving skills.

options.label: B
options.text: It can lead to increased anxiety and depression.

options.label: C
options.text: It can have no effect on mental health.

options.label: D
options.text: It can lead to increased self-confidence.

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) in regulating the tone of self-talk?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase negative self-talk and decrease positive self-talk.

options.label: B
options.text: To identify cycles of negative thoughts and replace them with neutral or more compassionate reflections.

options.label: C
options.text: To decrease self-talk altogether.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase self-doubt and anxiety.

title: How do dogs "see" with their noses? - Alexandra Horowitz

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about a dog's ability to smell?

options.label: A
options.text: They can smell only with one nostril.

options.label: B
options.text: They can smell things that are 100 million times less concentrated than what humans can detect.

options.label: C
options.text: They can smell things that are only within a 5-foot radius.

options.label: D
options.text: They can smell only through their mouth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the vomeronasal organ responsible for in a dog's sense of smell?

options.label: A
options.text: Detecting the hormones released by other animals.

options.label: B
options.text: Detecting the direction of a smell.

options.label: C
options.text: Detecting the concentration of a smell.

options.label: D
options.text: Detecting the texture of a smell.

multiple-choice.question: What is special about the way a dog's nose processes smells?

options.label: A
options.text: It takes up less relative brain area than in humans.

options.label: B
options.text: It takes up many times more relative brain area in dogs than in humans.

options.label: C
options.text: It processes smells at a slower rate than in humans.

options.label: D
options.text: It processes smells at a faster rate than in humans.

multiple-choice.question: What can a dog's sense of smell detect that is invisible to humans?

options.label: A
options.text: The color of objects.

options.label: B
options.text: The texture of objects.

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of hormones released by other animals.

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of invisible objects.

multiple-choice.question: What can a dog's sense of smell reveal about the world around them?

options.label: A
options.text: Only the location of objects.

options.label: B
options.text: Only the presence of other animals.

options.label: C
options.text: A story from start to finish about the world around them.

options.label: D
options.text: Only the texture of objects.

title: How does your smartphone know your location? - Wilton L. Virgo

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why knowing the time on a satellite is crucial for determining a smartphone's location?

options.label: A
options.text: To calculate the distance to the satellite using the speed of light.

options.label: B
options.text: To determine the speed of the satellite.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the satellite's orbit around the Earth.

options.label: D
options.text: To know the time of day on the satellite.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary challenge in calculating the distance to a satellite using the speed of light?

options.label: A
options.text: The speed of light is too slow.

options.label: B
options.text: The signal arrival time is not accurate enough.

options.label: C
options.text: The distance to the satellite is too large.

options.label: D
options.text: The light is incredibly fast.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why atomic clocks are necessary for precise location determination?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more accurate than mechanical clocks.

options.label: B
options.text: They are less expensive than other types of clocks.

options.label: C
options.text: They can maintain a constant frequency.

options.label: D
options.text: They are powered by quantum mechanics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary advantage of using cesium 133 atoms as frequency standards in GPS satellites?

options.label: A
options.text: They are less expensive than other types of atoms.

options.label: B
options.text: They are more accurate than other types of atoms.

options.label: C
options.text: They oscillate at the same exact frequency.

options.label: D
options.text: They are powered by quantum mechanics.

multiple-choice.question: How many measurements are required to pinpoint a smartphone's location using GPS satellites?

title: The French Revolution: Crash Course World History #29

multiple-choice.question: What was the main problem with the French taxation system in the 18th century?

options.label: A
options.text: The nobles and clergy never paid taxes.

options.label: B
options.text: The king's power was too limited.

options.label: C
options.text: The French government was too decentralized.

options.label: D
options.text: The French economy was too dependent on agriculture.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the Tennis Court Oath?

options.label: A
options.text: It marked the beginning of the French Revolution.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a protest against the nobles and the clergy.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a promise by the Third Estate to create a new constitution.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a declaration of independence from France.

multiple-choice.question: What was the Declaration of Pillnitz?

options.label: A
options.text: A declaration by the French National Assembly promising to restore the monarchy.

options.label: B
options.text: A declaration by the Holy Roman Emperor and King William Frederick II of Prussia promising to restore the French monarchy.

options.label: C
options.text: A declaration by the French people promising to create a new constitution.

options.label: D
options.text: A declaration by the French king promising to reform the tax system.

multiple-choice.question: What was the Committee of Public Safety?

options.label: A
options.text: A committee that oversaw the creation of the French constitution.

options.label: B
options.text: A committee that was responsible for the Reign of Terror.

options.label: C
options.text: A committee that advised the French king on matters of state.

options.label: D
options.text: A committee that was responsible for the French economy.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Napoleon Bonaparte's rise to power?

options.label: A
options.text: He established a new constitution that gave more power to the people.

options.label: B
options.text: He established a new constitution that gave more power to the wealthy.

options.label: C
options.text: He became the First Consul of France and granted himself almost unlimited executive power.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a member of the Committee of Public Safety.

title: What triggers a chemical reaction? - Kareem Jarrah

multiple-choice.question: What does the term "enthalpy" refer to in the context of chemical reactions?

options.text: A measure of the total amount of energy in a system

options.label: B
options.text: An increase or decrease of energy during a chemical reaction

options.label: C
options.text: A measure of the randomness of a chemical's structure

options.label: D
options.text: A type of chemical reaction that releases energy

options.label: A
options.text: The reactant

options.label: B
options.text: The product or result of the reaction

options.label: C
options.text: The energy added to the system

options.label: D
options.text: The energy released by the system

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The cooking of dinner over a campfire

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: A type of chemical reaction that releases energy

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what happens to the energy in an exothermic reaction?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Could a blind eye regenerate? - David Davila

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a person's field of vision in diseases like Retinitis pigmentosa and Usher syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes slightly larger

options.label: B
options.text: It remains the same

options.label: C
options.text: It becomes slightly smaller and eventually leads to complete blindness

options.label: D
options.text: It changes colors

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of the zebrafish retina that is similar to the human retina?

options.label: A
options.text: It is made of different layers of cells

options.label: B
options.text: It is only made of rod photoreceptors

options.label: C
options.text: It is only made of cone photoreceptors

options.label: D
options.text: It is completely different from the human retina

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why photoreceptors in the human retina do not regenerate?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are damaged beyond repair

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not born with the ability to regenerate

options.label: C
options.text: Because they don't divide and multiply

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not needed

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of Müller glia in the regeneration of the zebrafish retina?

options.label: A
options.text: They help to destroy damaged photoreceptors

options.label: B
options.text: They help to repair damaged photoreceptors

options.label: C
options.text: They transform into stem cells and produce new photoreceptors

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What are the two chemicals that create activity in the brain and help to trigger the transformation of Müller glia into photoreceptors?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Glutamate and aminoadipate

options.label: C
options.text: Aminoadipate and insulin

options.label: D
options.text: Glutamate and adrenaline

title: How spontaneous brain activity keeps you alive - Nathan S. Jacobs

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the crucial automatically occurring activities in the brain that keeps us alive?

options.label: A
options.text: Spontaneous activity in the brainstem that controls our breathing

options.label: B
options.text: Ongoing neural activity that underlies our sensory perception

options.label: C
options.text: Central pattern generators that control simple repetitive behaviors

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

options.label: A
options.text: Central pattern generators

options.label: B
options.text: Retinal ganglion cells

options.label: C
options.text: Cortical oscillations

options.label: D
options.text: Thalamic activity

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Varied bursts of neural activity

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid eye movements and vivid dreams

options.label: D
options.text: Synchronized spontaneous activity

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the most interesting things about spontaneous brain function, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Its involvement in cognitive functions

options.label: B
options.text: Its role in rejuvenating cognitive capacity

options.label: C
options.text: Its involvement in one of the most mysterious and poorly understood phenomena of our bodies: sleep

options.label: D
options.text: Its ability to coordinate complex tasks

multiple-choice.question: What is the brain's autopilot involved in, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Only basic biological functions

options.label: B
options.text: Only cognitive functions

options.label: C
options.text: Complex tasks involving both cognitive and motor functions

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

title: How do vaccines work? - Kelwalin Dhanasarnsombut

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with creating the first vaccine in 1796?

options.label: A
options.text: Louis Pasteur

options.label: B
options.text: Edward Jenner

options.label: C
options.text: Alexander Fleming

options.label: D
options.text: Robert Koch

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the immune system in defending against contagious diseases?

options.label: A
options.text: To trigger a series of responses to identify and remove foreign microbes from the body

options.label: B
options.text: To create a long-lasting immunity to specific pathogens

options.label: C
options.text: To isolate specific components of antigens to prompt specific responses

options.label: D
options.text: To weaken and inactivate pathogens to prevent the full-blown disease

multiple-choice.question: What type of vaccine is made from one part of the pathogen, called an antigen?

options.label: A
options.text: Live attenuated vaccine

options.label: B
options.text: Inactive vaccine

options.label: C
options.text: Subunit vaccine

options.label: D
options.text: DNA vaccine

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of DNA vaccines over other types of vaccines?

options.label: A
options.text: They create long-lasting immunity to specific pathogens

options.label: B
options.text: They are easier to make and administer

options.label: C
options.text: They instruct cells in the body to make antigens, causing a stronger immune response

options.label: D
options.text: They contain no other ingredients from the rest of the pathogen that could develop into the disease

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of continuing the development of vaccines?

options.label: A
options.text: To treat diseases like HIV, malaria, or Ebola

options.label: B
options.text: To create a long-lasting immunity to specific pathogens

options.label: C
options.text: To weaken and inactivate pathogens to prevent the full-blown disease

options.label: D
options.text: To isolate specific components of antigens to prompt specific responses

title: The evolution of the human eye - Joshua Harvey

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial structure of the human eye, according to the transcript?

options.label: B
options.text: A pinhole eye with a lens

options.label: C
options.text: A simple light spot found in single-celled organisms

options.label: D
options.text: A front-facing retina with no blind spot

options.label: B
options.text: To maintain the structure of the eye

options.label: C
options.text: To secrete a protective film

options.label: D
options.text: To process sharper and more colorful images

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is inverted, with light-detecting cells facing away from the eye opening

options.label: C
options.text: Because it has a reflective layer maximizing the amount of light the eye can detect

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is one example of an eye adaptation in the animal kingdom that allows for excellent night vision?

options.label: A
options.text: A front-facing retina

options.label: B
options.text: A reflective layer maximizing the amount of light the eye can detect

options.label: C
options.text: A pinhole effect reducing distortion

options.label: D
options.text: A colored ring controlling the amount of light entering the eye

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential application of studying the human eye's structure and function?

options.label: B
options.text: To develop new types of communication devices

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Underwater Explosions (Science with Alan Sailer!)

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the experiment being conducted by Destin and Alan Sailer?

options.label: A
options.text: To study the effects of high-speed photography on explosions.

options.label: B
options.text: To investigate the phenomenon of cavitation in liquids.

options.label: C
options.text: To determine the optimal exposure time for capturing underwater explosions.

options.label: D
options.text: To test the hypothesis that explosions can create a shockwave that can be seen in high-speed footage.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the main difference between Destin's theory and Alan's theory about the behavior of the bottle after detonation?

options.label: A
options.text: Destin believes the bottle is blown out, while Alan thinks it's sucked in.

options.label: B
options.text: Destin thinks the cap is pushed forward, while Alan believes it's sucked in.

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the phenomenon where a liquid turns into vapor due to a decrease in pressure?

options.label: B
options.text: Condensation

options.label: C
options.text: Cavitation

options.label: D
options.text: Phase transition

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The shockwave from the explosion creates a low-pressure spot in the liquid.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The heat from the explosion causes the liquid to expand.

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: What is a gift economy? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of a gift economy?

options.label: A
options.text: Gifts given without explicit conditions are used to accumulate material wealth.

options.label: B
options.text: Gifts given with explicit conditions are used to foster a system of social ties and obligations.

options.label: C
options.text: Gifts given without explicit conditions are used to foster a system of social ties and obligations.

options.label: D
options.text: Gifts given with explicit conditions are used to accumulate social wealth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "kula ring"?

options.label: A
options.text: A system of trade where people exchange goods for goods.

options.label: B
options.text: A system of trade where people exchange goods for services.

options.label: C
options.text: A system of exchange where shell necklaces and arm bands are traded without practical use.

options.label: D
options.text: A system of exchange where people trade goods for material wealth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a gift economy and a barter system?

options.label: A
options.text: A gift economy involves haggling over prices, while a barter system does not.

options.label: B
options.text: A gift economy involves the exchange of goods or services for other goods or services, while a barter system involves the exchange of goods or services for money.

options.label: C
options.text: A gift economy involves gifts given without any preconditions or haggling, while a barter system involves gifts given with preconditions or haggling.

options.label: D
options.text: A gift economy involves the accumulation of material wealth, while a barter system involves the accumulation of social wealth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a gift economy in a communal space like Burning Man?

options.label: A
options.text: To accumulate material wealth.

options.label: B
options.text: To establish a market system for other exchanges.

options.label: C
options.text: To foster a system of social ties and obligations.

options.label: D
options.text: To accumulate social wealth.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a gift economy emerging as an alternative to intellectual property?

options.label: A
options.text: A system of trade where people exchange goods for money.

options.label: B
options.text: A system of exchange where artists, musicians, and open-source developers distribute their creative works for financial profit.

options.label: C
options.text: A system of exchange where artists, musicians, and open-source developers distribute their creative works not for financial profit, but to raise their social profile or establish their community role.

options.label: D
options.text: A system of trade where people exchange services for material wealth.

title: The Atlantic slave trade: What too few textbooks told you - Anthony Hazard

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary reason for the Atlantic slave trade?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide labor for European industries.

options.label: B
options.text: To establish colonies in the Americas.

options.label: C
options.text: To meet the demand for labor in the Americas due to a lack of settlers and indentured servants.

options.label: D
options.text: To spread Christianity in Africa.

multiple-choice.question: What was the demographic effect of the Atlantic slave trade on Africa?

options.label: A
options.text: The continent gained a large population of able-bodied men.

options.label: B
options.text: The continent lost tens of millions of its able-bodied population, with most slaves taken being men.

options.label: C
options.text: The continent's population remained stable due to the slave trade.

options.label: D
options.text: The continent's population increased due to the influx of European settlers.

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary justification for the Atlantic slave trade in Europe and the Americas?

options.label: A
options.text: The need for labor in the colonies.

options.label: B
options.text: The desire to spread Christianity in Africa.

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that Africans were biologically inferior and destined to be slaves.

options.label: D
options.text: The practice of intertribal warfare.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the Atlantic slave trade on African kingdoms?

options.label: A
options.text: They prospered from the slave trade and became stronger.

options.label: B
options.text: They collapsed due to the loss of able-bodied men and the influx of European weapons.

options.label: C
options.text: They remained unaffected by the slave trade.

options.label: D
options.text: They became more unstable due to the slave trade.

multiple-choice.question: What was the treatment of slaves on ships during the Atlantic slave trade?

options.label: A
options.text: They were treated with respect and dignity.

options.label: B
options.text: They were kept in good conditions and provided with adequate food and water.

options.label: C
options.text: They were cramped below deck, with poor sanitation, and many died of disease or were thrown overboard.

options.label: D
options.text: They were treated as equals to the crew.

title: I'm Batman - Amy Wray

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main misconceptions about bats?

options.label: A
options.text: That they are blind and rely solely on echolocation.

options.label: B
options.text: That they are vampires and feed on human blood.

options.label: C
options.text: That they are blind and have poor eyesight.

options.label: D
options.text: That they are only found in caves.

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique feature of bats that has inspired technological advancements?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to fly at high speeds.

options.label: B
options.text: Their echolocation abilities.

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to true powered flight.

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to fly for long distances.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main cause of white-nose syndrome in bats?

options.label: A
options.text: Climate change and habitat destruction.

options.label: B
options.text: Fungal infection.

options.label: C
options.text: Rabies virus.

options.label: D
options.text: Insect-borne disease.

multiple-choice.question: What is a simple way to provide shelter for bats?

options.label: A
options.text: Installing a bat box.

options.label: B
options.text: Using pesticides to control insect populations.

options.label: C
options.text: Discouraging the use of bat-friendly habitats.

options.label: D
options.text: Handling bats in an attic or barn.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it not recommended to handle bats?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are a threat to human safety.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they may carry diseases such as rabies.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are a protected species.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are nocturnal animals.

title: At what moment are you dead? - Randall Hayes

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the ancient theory of vitalism?

options.label: A
options.text: That living things are unique because they are filled with a special substance or energy that is the essence of life.

options.label: B
options.text: That the human body is essentially no different from any other machine, brought to life by a divinely created soul.

options.label: C
options.text: That life is not contained in some magical substance or spark, but within the ongoing biological processes themselves.

options.label: D
options.text: That death is the process of increasing entropy that destroys the fragile balance of life.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the main reason organisms can't be simply sparked back to life once they've already died?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the breaking down of their molecules is irreversible.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the universal phenomenon of entropy means that molecules will tend towards diffusing randomly.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the many other processes involved in the respiratory cycle are no longer functioning.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the electric shock from a defibrillator can't jump-start an inanimate heart.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of cells using energy to maintain their molecules in complicated formations?

options.label: A
options.text: To allow them to break down into smaller molecules and atoms.

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent the universal phenomenon of entropy from occurring.

options.label: C
options.text: To maintain their biological functions and prevent death.

options.label: D
options.text: To allow them to diffuse randomly and move from areas of high concentration to low concentration.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the concept of cryonics?

options.label: A
options.text: To achieve the same as some animals by slowing down their biological processes to the point where they are virtually paused.

options.label: B
options.text: To freeze dying people and revive them later when newer technology is able to help them.

options.label: C
options.text: To inject all of the cells with ATP at the same time and cause the body to simply pick up where it left off.

options.label: D
options.text: To allow them to break down into smaller molecules and atoms.

multiple-choice.question: What is the point at which someone is completely dead, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A fixed constant that is determined by the amount of energy in their cells.

options.label: B
options.text: A matter of how much of the entropy we're currently capable of reversing.

options.label: C
options.text: A point that is determined by the number of molecules in their cells.

options.label: D
options.text: A point that is determined by the amount of ATP in their cells.

title: The 2,400-year search for the atom - Theresa Doud

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with proposing the idea that everything in the world is made up of tiny particles surrounded by empty space?

options.label: A
options.text: Aristotle

options.label: B
options.text: Democritus

options.label: C
options.text: John Dalton

options.label: D
options.text: J.J. Thompson

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the Quaker teacher who sought to challenge Aristotelian theory by showing that common substances always broke down into the same elements in the same proportions?

options.label: A
options.text: John Dalton

options.label: B
options.text: Democritus

options.label: C
options.text: J.J. Thompson

options.label: D
options.text: Ernest Rutherford

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of J.J. Thompson's discovery of the electron in 1897?

options.label: A
options.text: He won a Nobel Prize in 1906 for his electron discovery, but his model of the atom didn't stick around long.

options.label: B
options.text: He showed atoms as uniformly packed spheres of positive matter filled with negatively charged electrons.

options.label: C
options.text: He concluded that atoms consisted largely of empty space with just a few electrons.

options.label: D
options.text: He stipulated that electrons orbit the nucleus at fixed energies and distances.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Ernest Rutherford's experiment of shooting small, positively charged alpha particles at a sheet of gold foil?

options.label: A
options.text: He concluded that the foil was like a thin paper screen.

options.label: B
options.text: He concluded that the atom's thinly dispersed positive charge would not be enough to deflect the particles in any one place.

options.label: C
options.text: He concluded that atoms consisted largely of empty space with just a few electrons.

options.label: D
options.text: He concluded that the foil was like a thick net with a very large mesh.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current model of the atom, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The chocolate chip cookie model of the atom

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The quantum model

options.label: D
options.text: The uncertainty principle

title: What are those floaty things in your eye? - Michael Mauser

options.text: Muscae volitantes

options.label: B
options.text: Vitreous humor

options.label: C
options.text: Retina

options.label: D
options.text: Floater

multiple-choice.question: What are floaters, according to the transcript?

options.text: Bits of tissue, red blood cells, or clumps of protein suspended within the vitreous humor of the eye

options.label: B
options.text: External objects that enter the eye

options.label: C
options.text: Shadows on the retina caused by external objects

options.label: D
options.text: Moving dots of light caused by white blood cells

multiple-choice.question: What is the blue field entoptic phenomenon?

options.label: A
options.text: A visual phenomenon where tiny dots of light dart about when looking at a bright blue sky

options.label: B
options.text: A condition where abnormally numerous or large floaters interfere with vision

options.label: C
options.text: A sign of a more serious condition requiring immediate medical treatment

options.label: D
options.text: A gentle reminder that what we think we see depends on our biology and minds

multiple-choice.question: What causes the blue field entoptic phenomenon?

options.label: A
options.text: White blood cells moving through the capillaries along the retina's surface

options.label: B
options.text: Red blood cells moving through the capillaries along the retina's surface

options.label: C
options.text: Shadows on the retina caused by external objects

options.label: D
options.text: External objects that enter the eye

options.label: A
options.text: Abnormally numerous or large floaters that interfere with vision

options.label: B
options.text: Abnormally few or small floaters that do not interfere with vision

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of blue sky sprites

options.label: D
options.text: The absence of floaters

options.label: C

title: How does cancer spread through the body? - Ivan Seah Yu Jun

multiple-choice.question: What is the process of cancer spreading across the body called?

options.label: A
options.text: Tumor growth

options.label: B
options.text: Cancer invasion

options.label: C
options.text: Metastasis

options.label: D
options.text: Cell division

options.label: A
options.text: Transcoelomic spread

options.label: B
options.text: Lymphatic spread

options.label: C
options.text: Hematogenous spread

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

options.label: A
options.text: The location of the vascular and lymphatic channels

options.label: B
options.text: The properties of the cancer cells

options.label: C
options.text: The effectiveness of the immune system

options.label: D
options.text: The microenvironment of the target site

options.label: A
options.text: Chemotherapy

options.label: B
options.text: Radiation therapy

options.label: C
options.text: Immunotherapy

options.label: D
options.text: Surgery

multiple-choice.question: What are interleukins, and how are they used in immunotherapy?

options.label: A
options.text: Interleukins are chemicals secreted by the immune cells of the body, and they are used to stimulate the growth and activity of immune cells.

options.label: B
options.text: Interleukins are chemicals that destroy cancer cells, and they are used to treat cancer.

options.label: C
options.text: Interleukins are chemicals that stimulate the growth of cancer cells, and they are used to treat cancer.

options.label: D
options.text: Interleukins are chemicals that have no effect on cancer cells, and they are not used to treat cancer.
